title: Block launcher and horizontal distance equation

content.question:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

A spring-loaded launcher can be securely attached to a tabletop. When the spring is at its uncompressed length, the plunger is in the position shown above in Figure 1. A small wood block can be pressed against the end of the plunger, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure 2. When the block is released, the plunger pushes the block along the tabletop. Two pins are attached to the edge of the table to prevent the plunger from extending beyond the table. When the plunger hits the pins, the block then leaves the table. There is nonnegligible friction between the block and the tabletop.

The launcher can be moved closer to or farther from the edge of the tabletop. Students set up tables 1 and 2, as shown above, with tabletops that are made of the same material. On table 1, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="s equals A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is slightly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On table 2, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="s equals B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is significantly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On both tables, the block is released from rest and loses contact with the plunger at the moment the plunger reaches the pins. Tables 1 and 2 are the same height.

<math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the spring constant of the spring.

<math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the mass of the block.

<math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance the spring is compressed.

<math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu) is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the tabletop.

<math alttext="s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop.

Assume the spring is ideal, the plunger has negligible mass, the block loses contact with the plunger immediately after it reaches the end of the table, and there is non-negligible friction between the tabletops and the blocks.

(a) Without manipulating equations, explain why the block launched from table 1 could land farther from the table than the block launched from table 2 does.

frqParts.text:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

A spring-loaded launcher can be securely attached to a tabletop. When the spring is at its uncompressed length, the plunger is in the position shown above in Figure 1. A small wood block can be pressed against the end of the plunger, compressing the spring a distance <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in Figure 2. When the block is released, the plunger pushes the block along the tabletop. Two pins are attached to the edge of the table to prevent the plunger from extending beyond the table. When the plunger hits the pins, the block then leaves the table. There is nonnegligible friction between the block and the tabletop.

The launcher can be moved closer to or farther from the edge of the tabletop. Students set up tables 1 and 2, as shown above, with tabletops that are made of the same material. On table 1, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="s equals A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is slightly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On table 2, the launcher is positioned so that the distance <math alttext="s equals B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop is significantly less than <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. On both tables, the block is released from rest and loses contact with the plunger at the moment the plunger reaches the pins. Tables 1 and 2 are the same height.

<math alttext="k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the spring constant of the spring.

<math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the mass of the block.

<math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance the spring is compressed.

<math alttext="mu" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (mu) is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the block and the tabletop.

<math alttext="s" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the distance between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop.

Assume the spring is ideal, the plunger has negligible mass, the block loses contact with the plunger immediately after it reaches the end of the table, and there is non-negligible friction between the tabletops and the blocks.

(a) Without manipulating equations, explain why the block launched from table 1 could land farther from the table than the block launched from table 2 does.
(b) Does the block launched from table 1 spend more, less, or the same amount of time in the air than the block launched from table 2 does? Explain your reasoning.

(c) Consider the Earth-block system. Determine the change, if any, in the total mechanical energy of the system from the instant the block leaves the table to the instant immediately before it reaches the ground.

The students correctly derive an equation for the horizontal distance <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the edge of the tabletop that the block lands, in terms of <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> (the distance between the launcher and the edge of the tabletop):
<math alttext="D equals t times the square root of, the fraction k over m, end fraction, times, open parenthesis, 2 L s minus s squared, close parenthesis, minus 2 mu g s, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>t</mi><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>L</mi><mi>s</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>μ</mi><mi>g</mi><mi>s</mi></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>,
where <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the time interval between the instant the block leaves the table and the instant immediately before it reaches the ground.
(d) Does this equation for <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> support your argument from part (a) that the block launched from table 1 could land farther from the table than the block launched from table 2? Briefly explain why or why not.

(e) The students now use the same setups to launch blocks that are identical to each other but more massive than the original blocks. The blocks are made of the same material as the original blocks. Does this change in the mass of the blocks make it more likely or less likely that the block launched from table 1 goes farther than the block launched from table 2 does? Briefly explain your reasoning.

(f) Two students each try to sketch a graph of the kinetic energy of the block as a function of its position from launch to the time the block reaches the edge of the table. Their graphs are shown above. Which graph best represents the kinetic energy of the block? Justify your selection.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
